bibl.title: Letter from Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed to Philip Showalter Hench, May 5, 1954

div1.p: Reed describes the presentation of the Finlay Medals at the Cuban Embassy in Washington, D.C. and explains that because he is in the Army, he cannot obtain his medal until he receives Congressional approval.

div1.head: Letter from Lawrence [Walter L.] Reed to Philip Showalter Hench, May 5, 1954
div1.opener:
Major General Walter Lawrence Reed
2810 Thirty Sixth Place
Washington, D. C.
May 5th- '54
Dear Doctor Hench.
div1.p:
We were all so sorry to learn
that you had been ill, but delighted to know
you were on the up & up. I know you
would have enjoyed the Finlay celebration at the
Cuban Embassy - It really was a most
impressive affair. The Ambasador read
in English quite a lengthy statement, giving
the background, the work of the American
Commission and of your efforts to have
the place where the Commission did its work
restored and made an historical shrine and we
were all so sorry toyou could not have been
there to receive in person the beautiful
medal. Blossom enjoyed to the extent
that she kissed the Embasador when
AC
R
he presented the medal to her. General
Armstrong, (Surg Genl.) made a perfectly
wonderful address expressing the co-operation
which this ceremony demonstrated between our
two countries - He is a delightful speaker.
Gen Love & Col. Siler were both there - I
understood that Col Siler was there to represent
you - That was a difficult task. I
had to turn my medal over to the Army
who would send it to the Intake Desk
who in turn would try to get Congressional
approval for me to accept it - I understand
it will take six months. Hope you
havent been too disturbed over the McCarthy
hearing - Hoping you are entirely well
by now & will soon be in Washington
on a business trip & that we will see you
then, With Kindest Regards-
